title-group.article-title: Rheumatoid Nodule of the Vocal Cord

author-notes.corresp: Asmaa Gaber Abdou, Department of Pathology, Faculty of Medicine, Menofiya University, Shebein Elkom 002, Egypt Email: asmaa_elsaidy@yahoo.com

body.p: This case is of a 45-year-old woman who presented with hoarseness of voice for years with a history of controlled rheumatoid arthritis. She was submitted to laryngoscope that detected right vocal cord polyp. The excised polyp was examined histopathologically and showed normal stratified squamous epithelial covering with an underlying multiple nodules (Figure 1A). Each nodule was formed of central fibrinoid necrosis and surrounded by histiocytic collections arranged in a palisaded manner (Figure 1B-D). The periphery of each nodule showed lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate.

caption.p: Section examined from the excised polyp showed normal stratified squamous epithelial covering (A). The underlying mucosa showed classic features of rheumatoid nodule manifested by central fibrinoid necrosis surrounded by palisaded histiocytes and lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate (B, C, and D) (hematoxylin and eosin staining ×50 for A, ×100 for B, ×200 for C, ×400 for D)

body.p: Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the synovial membrane of articular joints. In 20% of patients, extra-articular manifestations are present, including rheumatoid nodule formation that is commonly seen subcutaneously at areas of pressure points.1 Rheumatoid nodule was also described to affect other sites such as lung, heart, and larynx.2 Affection of vocal cord by rheumatoid nodule is one of the manifestations of laryngeal rheumatoid arthritis that may also show cricoarytenoiditis, amyloidosis, and secondary Sjogren’s syndrome.3 Laryngeal rheumatoid nodule has been described earlier in several studies, including in case reports.1,4-6
